Group II U.S. air carrier  * One of the largest airlines in the US just ceased operations but most flyers wouldn't even recognize it – here's why
***
ExpressJet, like most airlines, started 2020 strong. A steady stream of pilots and flight attendants were eager to join its ranks and United Airlines had entrusted the carrier with flying a new, larger aircraft type, the Embraer E175, less than a year earlier (para. 1).
After evaluating its regional network, United selected rival regional carrier CommutAir to exclusively fly the ERJ145, crippling ExpressJet. The July 30 announcement gave employees two months' notice that the airline would be ceasing operations.
With air travel still at reduced levels, it was clear that ExpressJet wouldn't find a home elsewhere and the airline agreed to close its doors on September 30, ending a 41-year history for the airline that can trace its earliest routes to Atlantic Southeast Airlines in 1979.
ExpressJet also wasn't the only regional airline to go under in 2020 with other carriers included Compass Airlines, flying for Delta and American
And Trans States Airlines, flying exclusively for United.
*
Reference

According to Madhu Unnikrishnan of Skift, “Travel recovery may be starting, but it may not be enough to save thousands of U.S. airline jobs. Unless Congress acts to extend payroll protections, mass layoffs could start on October 1. Bankruptcy isn’t likely this time around, as airlines still have access to capital, as a flurry of recent stock, bond, and asset sale transactions clearly show. No U.S. airline is anywhere close to running low on cash”. We now know that Congress has tabled any future discussions regarding a broader coronavirus economic relief package until after the election, the airline industry is seeking to push for a stand-alone bill that would pay front-line workers for an additional six months (Aratani, 2020). “After Congress missed the Sept. 30 deadline for approving an extension, another stand-alone bill was introduced, to provide $25.5 billion to passenger airlines, $3 billion to airline contractors and $300 million to cargo carriers. As a condition of accepting the money, airlines would have to reinstate furloughed employees and provide them with back pay. But the measure failed to advance” (Aratani, 2020).  Given what we know to be true, and due to the inability for Congress to pass any sort of bipartisan agreement or provide an extension to current payroll protections and that airline companies are beginning to layoff and/or furlough employees, I believe outside pressure will continue to mount and Congress will be forced into some sort of action. With that being said, I will assess a low percentage of 25% chance that one of the eighteen Group III U.S. Air Carriers file for bankruptcy.

Between 15 May 2020 and 30 November 2020, will any Group III U.S. carrier file for bankruptcy?
Once again, Covid-19 is a major contributing factor to the survival of group III carriers. Travel has taken a dramatic hit because of the pandemic, “on Wednesday, Transportation Security Administration officers screened just shy of 95,000 people at airport checkpoints, a dramatic drop from the 2.3 million who passed through on the equivalent day in 2019” (Wallace, 2020). Airlines are losing money at a rapid rate and are having very little attendance, 
“even as Delta and the other major airlines in the United States dramatically slash schedules, they are averaging an anemic 23 passengers on each domestic flight and losing $350 million to $400 million a day as expenses like payroll, rent and aircraft maintenance far exceed the money they are brining in” (Chokshi, 2020). 
Even though airlines are losing money at a consistent rate, group III carries have survived. Airlines have been able to survive by taking on debt, “$67 billion of the new debt is composed f government loans ($50 billion), deferred taxes ($5 billion) and loan guarantees ($12 billion)” (Garcia, 2020). Another way airlines have been able to survive is through furloughs, “United Airlines and American Airlines have sent furlough notices to a total of more than 32,000 employees, saying they can’t afford to have them on payroll after Thursday-the expiration date for the federal CARES Act Payroll Support Program” (NPR,2020). Like all industries, air travel has been greatly affected. However, not every airline will furlough their employees, “‘Southwest has no current plans for furloughs,’ a company representative tells NPR, citing cost-cutting and voluntary agreements with workers. Delta is in a similar position” (NPR, 2020). The airline industry is grim. However, it is my belief that group III U.S. carriers will do everything in their power to avoid declaring bankruptcy. While Virgin has already declared bankruptcy, I do not believe anyone else will. Between government loans, restructuring, and pay cuts, airlines will be able to survive until the end of November, 2020.

With domestic and international travel severely impacted by the Covid-19 pandemic, the 18 Group III US air carriers have been forced to adapt (Josephs, 2020). To be classified as a 
Group III air carrier, companies must have operating revenue boundaries of over $1 billion (Chadwick, 2019). Airlines are currently transitioning to cater to leisure travelers as business travel largely halted in midst of the pandemic and damaged economy with an observed 58% decrease in travel observed in April 2020 compared to 2019 (Josephs, 2020; Nguyen & Animashaun, 2020). The air industry received a $25 billion bailout in mid-April to keep them afloat through September (Rappeport & Chokshi, 2020). However, with no second bailout currently reached, airlines have begun to shrink through employee layoffs and groundings of aircraft to remain afloat (Egan, 2020).
	With talks about a second economic relief bill at a standstill, the airlines are expected to continue to shrink up to 50% and continue to reduce prices and erroneous fees to entice travelers to purchase tickets (Egan, 2020; Josephs, 2020). According to Oscar Munoz former CEO of United Airlines, while the situation is dire and numerous airlines have filed for bankruptcy in the previous two decades following 9/11 and the recession, with layoffs and fleet reductions major carriers likely to survive through the year (Egan, 2020). While additional bailouts may not be reached prior to or even immediately after the election on 3 November, layoffs, fleet reductions, minor increases in leisure travel observed due to incentives, and roughly one and a half months left, I estimate there is a 10% probability that a Group III US air carrier will declare bankruptcy by 30 November.

https://www.forbes.com/sites/danielreed/2020/10/01/airline-layoffs-american-united-southwest/#78375b2c6d27 "According to Rapid Ratings International, which tracks and analyzes the financial health of most of the world’s publicly owned companies, all three of those airlines [Avianca, LATAM Group, and Groupo Aeromexico] had “Financial Heath Ratings” below 40 just prior to their bankruptcy filings. Now, the nation’s three biggest conventional airlines – American, Delta and United – all have FHRs below 40. That doesn’t mean that all three are destined to enter bankruptcy, but it does mean their chances of doing so are greatly heightened. Much smaller JetBlue’s Financial Health Rating is not in the danger zone, but at 43, it’s in danger of falling into that range if it has to borrow more money or suffers, as expected, more large GAAP losses and continues to burn through its cash reserves. Southwest, the nation’s largest carrier in passengers boarded but not in miles flown because it has very little international service, has an FHR of 72. That’s three times better than American’s FHR of 24. United, according to Rapid Ratings, has an FHR of 36; Delta’s FHR is 39. American now has the largest debt burden of the three at around $45 billion after drawing $7.5 billion in loans this week from the Treasury Department and closing last week on another $1.2 billion loan from Goldman Sachs. And with the combination of dramatically reduced staffs and fleets, it’s increasingly doubtful that any of those three carriers will be able to generate enough revenue to be able to both make their debt payments and earn large enough returns to satisfy investors. And it likely will become increasingly difficult, if not impossible for them to attract new sources of liquidity they’ll likely to need to stay alive, or sources for additional loans they will need to begin growing again if or when travel demand picks up significantly."

Group III U.S. air carriers are the top air carriers with operating revenues of over $1 billion.  (Chadwick, 2020).  These air carriers have been kept afloat by the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES Act), which extended payroll support to businesses and was signed into law on 27 March 2020. (Department of the Treasury, 2020).  Unfortunately, the CARES Act expired on 30 September.  This triggered layoffs at American Airlines and United Airlines, with Southwest Airlines warning layoffs could be coming soon (Ackley, 2020). Congress is currently considering an extension to the Payroll Support Program, but it is unknown if passing such a bill is likely to happen.  In fact, it is more likely that this bill is not passed due to the political considerations of the coming election.  It’s no secret that President Trump is running on a platform which includes his economic success.  Massive layoffs in the weeks before Election Day might be considered desirable by his political opponents in the House of Representatives.   While President Trump might also consider using an Executive Order to extend payroll protection, he may not do so, electing to blame the lack of a bill on the Democrats.  There are several ways in which an extension which saves the Group III carriers does not happen, and only one in which it does – bipartisan majorities in both houses of Congress agreeing to put politics aside to save jobs.  This is assuming such a bill is not spiked with a poison pill rider, which is also very possible.  Trump might sign the bill even if it included funding for liberal think tanks, simply to avoid responsibility for lost jobs. I’m going to rate it as highly unlikely (5-10%) that legislative or executive action is taken before the election. The question is, can Group III carriers survive without payroll protection?  I believe the answer is yes.  Congress is not the body which can extend money to the airlines.  The airlines themselves have significant assets, to include their fleets and part ownership in airline terminals, which they can mortgage to obtain collateral for loans.  These loans can also be less secure, with higher interest, and I think it’s very likely that big banks will be willing to make these loans.   I also think that after the election, Congress will be willing to pass the bill, whether Trump wins election or is a lame duck.  The question of survivability for the carriers, in my estimation, is only valid until the week after the election.  I believe that the airlines can survive the next 45 days, even without Congressional support.  I rate the confidence level at 70% that no Group III air carrier will declare bankruptcy by 30 November. Using historical bankruptcies of group III carriers since 2002, got a base rate of 0.61 bankruptcies per year. Then used a poisson dist (seems like an okay model choice) to estimate that there is a .46 chance of nonzero bankruptcies in any year. Given that we're only estimating until nov 30 and 2/3 of the year has passed, I should lower this probability. Then, given all covid news, I should increase the prob. Don't have a great way to do these bayesian updates but I'll say net effect is lowering probability from 0.46

Baseline: Very similar to my colleagues, the most reliable way to predict the default probability for the carriers is looking at the default probabilities in the market (near-term CDS). Therefore, we arrive at our baseline as follows: P(no default) = (1 - P(Alaska default)) * (1 - P(Allegiant default)) * ... * (1 - P(UPS default)). This gives us a probability of ~8%. Adjustments:
Private companies:
One of the more obvious problems with this approach is that there are some companies that are private and thus do not have market implied default probabilities. To mitigate this problem, we looked at companies that have a high correlation with the private company (i.e. are public comparables) and looked at their default probabilities. Even though this is definitely not 100% correct, as there are idiosyncratic risk factors that this public comp analysis does not take into account, this is the fastest and quite accurate way of prediction without going into the publicly available reports of the companies and doing complex fundamental analyses.
Assumption of independence:
The main problem with this approach is the fact that we do not think about the cross correlation terms between these occurrences. I.e. if one of the airlines is getting closer to bankruptcy, the other airlines will move closer to bankruptcy as well.
News updates:
The current administration has been very open to bailing out airlines early on and the administration has been lately discussing the possibility of another help package for airlines after some airlines suggested that they will need to cut a substantial part of their workforce after the first bailout funds are emptied (https://www.dallasnews.com/business/airlines/2020/08/26/could-a-second-airline-bailout-come-by-white-house-executive-order/). Conclusion: We increase our initial independent forecast by 50% to account for cross correlation, but we feel comfortable with this value given that we see it likely that the administration will give some temporary aid to these carriers if they need to. We do not need to worry about the size and scope of the help package either because we only need to predict until November 30.

This question is quite difficult to forecast, especially seeing there doesn't seem to be much news relating to airlines bankruptcy over the past few months. One very important thing to recognize is that Congress approved a $50B bailout ($25B in loans, $25B in grants) to the airline industry earlier this year, which is massive considering that marketcaps of the largest airline companies (excluding UPS) now are around ~20B. It's also important to recognize that many of the 18 airlines listed have significantly smaller market caps <$5B, thus the total bailout is quite substantial for the airline industry. There are also talks that airlines may receive another bailout following the Sept. 30 date when airlines may start laying off some of their employees. All in all, however, it seems that likelihood of bankruptcy before Nov. 30, 2020 aren't as large due to the large amount of funding granted by the government, but the financial health for airlines in the future is still very undetermined.

I used the implied 3 month default probability from Bloomberg (this is the closest tenor to the prediction range). For companies that were owned by a holding company, I used that holding company's default probability. For Kalitta, this company seemed to be privately held so I estimated a 0.58% probability based on the average of the other companies. Therefore P(at least one defaults) = 1 - P(none default) = 1 - P(Alaska doesn't default) P(Allegiant doesn't default) ... (this is assuming independence which we will address) = 0.10. Now there is obviously an argument that these default probabilities do not fully capture pairwise correlation between defaults due to the structure of the market. I think this is difficult to value since it is not abundantly clear to me that if one of these companies defaulted, that the US government would allow another air carrier company to default (similar to 08 bailout of auto names). Nonetheless, I will assign a 10% correlation premium, bringing the probability to 20%.

Implied market from CDS is just under 20% if assuming that 40% of the 1 year implied default rate is contained in the next three months. However, this assumes no correlation, and while I'm not assuming perfect correlation, I think there would be pairwise correlation closer to 0.3. Since it is difficult to model joint distributions across 18 variables with only pairwise correlations, I'll assign a rough 50% premium to the default rate, giving me something slightly under 30%. I'll also adjust this slightly given the crowd consensus, but I am more inclined to believe the CDS markets.

For most airlines, the business model is to hold down costs (and thus fares) by minimizing passenger comfort, convenience, and general satisfaction.  This was starting to slip before The Current Unpleasantness, but many carriers have returned to the sardine-tin approach as they clutch for revenue by getting cheeks back in the chairs.   However, there is some danger that more businesses than previously will substitute unsatisfactory on-line conferences for unsatisfactory airline experiences, the former being vastly less expensive, and that ordinary mortals will cut back on air travel at least until Kindly Doc Fauci sounds the all-clear, and they may not flock back to the airports even then.  Thus, there will likely continue to be relatively fewer souls on board even as contagion concerns decline. If you are an airline, there is a severe limit on how many employees you can lay off or dismiss.  Flight crew and maintenance folks pretty much need to be there, and executives do not lay each other off.  Fuel prices are what they are, and the prices of gate slots are fixed at least in the short term.  Sooner or later at least one Group III carrier will throw in the towel.  However, they can probably wheedle enough cash out of the gummint to keep the wolf from the cockpit door for a few more months.  Or maybe not.

Working on some math to see if my intuition is correct that it is better to *over wager* early on sudden death type questions like this. Seems like the way to check is calculate your Expected Brier Score, meaning, what your Brier Score would be on average for a question assuming you are handicapping it perfectly. For instance, say you think Event A has a uniform chance of happening over the course of 12 months of 80%. You could wager 80% at the start, reducing as time expires at an average rate of 20% (or 25% of your wager) per quarter. But my guess is a linearly sloped  reduction isn't optimal for this reason: if Event A happens, it could happen at any time. OTOH, if it doesn't happen, it doesn't happen at the end of 12 months every time, meaning the average of all your forecasts are counted when the event doesn't happen, whereas when it does happen only your forecasts to-date are scored. So you want forecasts-to-date as high as possible when the event occurs and as low as possible when not. Morever, this gives the *early* forecasts much more weight than *late* forecasts when the event does occur because the early forecasts exist in more universes than the late forecasts, so to speak.  I'll try to put some math (by math I mean spreadsheet simulations) to this over the weekend. I suspect I'm just re-inventing the wheel with this thinking, but it"s fun.

I'm starting over. The base rate for (at least one) Group III airline bankruptcies seems to be about 35% over the last twenty years, about 17% in a given six-month-period. So any individual airline has about a 1.5% chance of declaring bankruptcy in any given two-quarter period. Okay, now let's start looking at balance sheets. Here's American's Q1 balance sheet (https://s21.q4cdn.com/616071541/files/doc_news/assets/2020/1Q-2020-Financial-Results.pdf). Looks like they're paying about half a billion per quarter in debt service. American is up to about 100,000 passengers per day from a low of about 30,000 passengers per day. Seems like the average is about 500,000 per day. On average, they make about $10b per quarter, of which 75% is passengers. They typically also have roughly $10b in operating expenses. American will declare bankruptcy if they can no longer service their debt. Let's suppose that their revenue has dropped 80%, in line with the number of passengers, so they'll have $2b revenues per quarter. A lot of their costs will also drop- salaries, fuel, maintenance, marketing, and hotels *should* also drop. Prima facie, it seems like they should be able to move money around in order to service their debt. American also has $8b in assets, of which about half a billion is in cash. So they should be able to pay off their debt service at least through November, even if they have to sell assets to do it. I'm assuming here that they want to hold off on bankruptcy for as long as possible, since if they believe that demand will be depressed in the long term they have to know that bankruptcy may be inevitable. Taking a look at a few other balance sheets... Spirit was sitting on $1b cash at the end of 2020, and it looks like their debt service is around a quarter of a billion annually. How about freight? In 12/19, FedEx had $2b in cash, with debt service of almost $1b per *quarter.* Of course, they also have $65b in total assets, and it's not obvious to me that freight is suffering as much as passenger. How badly do companies want to avoid bankruptcy? I'm going to assume here that the management of these companies believes in maximizing shareholder value. If that's the case, then they'll do whatever they can to avoid bankruptcy. They may not succeed-- but I think the chances of what amounts to an instant bankruptcy before November are pretty slim. American, at least, will apparently have $11b cash on hand at the end of June (https://www.dallasnews.com/business/airlines/2020/05/10/airlines-are-racking-up-billions-in-debt-to-get-through-covid-19-can-they-survive-what-comes-next/), with loan repayments not due for years to come. I'm thinking near-term decisions and bailouts will rescue Group III airlines, but all it takes is one. I'll downgrade to sixty for now and hold.
